verses.text: Abijah rested with his ancestors, and they buried him in the city of David. Asa his son became king in his place. In his days the land had rest for ten years.
verses.comment: The verse follows the narrative style of the original text and clarifies pronouns for readability.

verses.text: Asa did what was good and right in the eyes of the LORD his God.
verses.comment: The phrase 'good and right' remains; 'in the eyes of the LORD' preserves original wording.

verses.text: He removed the foreign altars and the high places, broke down the pillars, and cut down the Asherah poles.
verses.comment: ‘Pillars’ is used instead of ‘sacred stones,’ matching common modern terms; Asherah poles is made explicit.

verses.text: He ordered Judah to seek the LORD, the God of their ancestors, and to obey His law and commandment.
He removed the high places and the incense altars from all the cities of Judah, and the kingdom was quiet under him.
verses.comment: ‘Incense altars’ is a direct translation of ‘sun images’ in alternative renderings.

verses.text: He built fortified cities in Judah, for the land was at peace. There was no war against him during those years, for the LORD gave him rest.
verses.comment: ‘At peace’ clarifies the meaning of ‘quiet’; ‘gave him rest’ maintains theological accuracy.

verses.text: He said to Judah, 'Let us build these cities and surround them with walls and towers, gates and bars. The land is still ours, because we have sought the LORD our God. We have sought Him, and He has given us rest on every side.' So they built and prospered.
Asa had an army of 300,000 men from Judah, armed with large shields and spears, and 280,000 men from Benjamin, who carried small shields and drew bows. All these were mighty men of valor.
verses.comment: Numbers rendered explicitly; ‘mighty men of valor’ kept from Hebrew idiom.

verses.text: Zerah the Cushite came out against them with an army of a million men and three hundred chariots; he marched as far as Mareshah.
verses.comment: ‘Cushite’ (Ethiopian) used per original Hebrew; numbers and place names retain clarity.

verses.text: Asa went out to meet him, and they drew up their battle lines in the Valley of Zephathah at Mareshah.
verses.comment: ‘Drew up their battle lines’ for ‘set the battle in array,’ modernizes phrasing.

verses.text: Asa called to the LORD his God and said, 'LORD, there is no one but You to help between the mighty and the powerless. Help us, LORD our God, for we rely on You, and in your name we have come against this multitude. LORD, You are our God; let not man prevail against You.'
verses.comment: Prayer wording kept as close to original as makes sense in modern English.

verses.text: So the LORD struck down the Cushites before Asa and Judah, and the Cushites fled.
verses.comment: ‘Struck down’ remains as literal as possible for ‘defeated.’

verses.text: Asa and his people pursued them as far as Gerar, and so many Cushites fell that none survived. They carried away very much plunder.
verses.comment: ‘Plunder’ rather than ‘spoil’ to reflect modern terminology.

verses.text: They attacked all the cities around Gerar, for the terror of the LORD was on them; they plundered all the cities, for there was much loot there.
verses.comment: ‘The terror of the LORD’ kept literal; ‘loot’ is modern term for ‘spoil.’

verses.text: They also attacked the tents of the herdsmen and carried off many sheep and camels. Then they returned to Jerusalem.
verses.comment: Sheep and camels specified per original text; phrase ‘tents of the herdsmen' retained.
